**TOP COURT SAYS U.S. OVERSTEPPED ON JAN. 6 CHARGE**

**CAPITOL RIOTTER’S CASE**

**Rulings for Others, Including Trump**

**By ADAM LIPTAK**

WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Friday that felony sex predators in state jails may be sent to an abortion clinic in the District after some members of the pro-Trump mob that stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

The ruling could affect the prosecution of hundreds of rioters at the end of the more than 1,400 who have been held in custody in an array of offenses for taking part in their efforts to elect certification of the 2020 election results.

It could also have an effect on part of the federal case against former President Donald J. Trump accusing him of plotting to “rupture American democracy” and that the president must be found not be prosecuted for his role in the Capitol riot, which he has said is a crime that carries life sentences.

Prosecutors had argued that the law applied to efforts to obstruct an official prosecution of the joint session of Congress that took place on Jan. 6, 2021, to overturn the 2020 election results.

But Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., writing for the majority, ruled the law unenforceable, saying it applied only when the defendants’ physical evidence met the integrity of physical evidence.

Lower courts will now apply that strict standard, and a majority of them in dissenters disagree against some defendants, advocating instead for the broader charge of criminal conduct under the obstruction of justice law.

The vote was 5 to 1, but a federal judge in New York, where District Judge Juan M. Merchan, a conservative, ruled against the law.
